awd_titl_txt: Elucidating Pressure- and Field-Tuned Phases and Multifunctionality in Magnetic Spinels
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract
"Magnetically responsive" materials have properties that can be tuned with pressure and magnetic field. Such materials exhibit a range of scientifically interesting and technologically useful properties. Understanding the physical mechanisms responsible for these exotic properties is not only important scientifically, but is an essential prerequisite to optimizing these materials for use in technological applications. This project combines the use of high pressures, high magnetic fields, and visible laser light to identify and control the underlying mechanisms responsible for magnetically responsive behavior in a select group of materials. The diverse techniques employed in this research, including high-pressure techniques using diamond anvil cell technology, high-magnetic-field and low-temperature methods, optical and laser techniques, and materials growth methods, provide the graduate student researchers outstanding training for a diverse range of careers in academia, industry, or national laboratories.  This project is also dedicated to imparting scientific literacy and enthusiasm for science in both the general public and K-12 students, through public lectures on science, middle-school scientific demonstrations, and lab tours that highlight the excitement of the materials studied, and the scientific techniques used in this project.  This project also includes efforts to increase the number and mentoring of underrepresented PhDs in STEM fields; to improve scientific communication skills of PhD students; and to provide guidance to current PhD students concerning their career paths.

Technical abstract
Magnetically frustrated materials, such as the magnetic spinels (chemical formula AB2X4), exhibit a range of diverse ground state phases and phenomena that can be sensitively tuned with pressure and magnetic field, including spin-spiral, charge-ordered, multiferroic, and spin/orbital-liquid phases.  The exceptional tunability of the spinels and other magnetically responsive materials make them excellent scientific laboratories in which myriad phases and phenomena can be sensitively controlled and studied.  Yet, there is limited microscopic understanding of the microscopic magnetostructural effects that lead to the important pressure- and field-tuned behaviors these materials exhibit, due largely to the absence of spectroscopic information that elucidates how the spin- and lattice-dynamics of magnetically frustrated materials change as functions of magnetic field and pressure.  The purpose of this research is to fill this important gap in our understanding by using inelastic light scattering techniques to study the spin- and lattice-excitations of select magnetically frustrated materials while field- and pressure-tuning through their diverse phases.  The goals of this research are to clarify the relationship between competing phases observed in different phase regions, to study as-yet-unexplored phase regimes and phenomena in magnetically frustrated materials as functions of temperature, pressure-, and magnetic-field, and to realize exotic new phases of matter that are of scientific or technological importance. This research also sheds light on the general conditions that are conducive to enhancing magnetoresponsive susceptibilities in magnetically frustrated materials; such information is an essential prerequisite to controlling these materials for useful technological applications.  In addition to providing diverse technical training to several graduate students, this research will impact the broader community through laboratory tours aimed at exposing K 12 students and teachers to the excitement of materials research and optics-related demonstrations to middle schools students; through efforts to improve the numbers and mentoring of underrepresented PhD students; and through scientific communication skills training of PhD students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview/Motivation: Magnetically responsive materials, such as the magnetic spinel compounds, are scientifically interesting and technologically useful because they exhibit diverse phases and properties that can be sensitively tuned with pressure and magnetic field.  The extreme sensitivity of these materials to applied magnetic field and strain make them both scientifically interesting and technological useful in applications such as icatalysis, electrochemistry, and magnetic shape memory.

The Intellectual Merit of this research project was that we were able to use our unique experimental capabilities to perform inelastic light scattering measurements as functions of magnetic field and pressure to discover and study the scientifically interesting and technologically useful magnetically responsive phases of spinel and other materials.

The Broader Impact outcomes of this project included:

(1). Advancing materials discovery and understanding while training three PhD students, including two female graduate students.

(2). Disseminating our scientific results in 6 publications, 3 PhD theses, and more than 20 invited and contributed presentations by the PI and involved graduate students; these publications and theses included:

(i). "Real-space magnetic imaging of the multiferroic spinels MnV2O4 and Mn3O4," B. Wolin et al., Physical Review Materials 2, 064407 (2018);

(ii). "Emergent vibronic excitations in the magnetodielectric regime of Ce2O3", A. Sethi et al., Physical Review Letters 122, 177601 (2019));

(iii). "Soft-mode behavior and evidence for pressure-induced magnetostructural effects in Pr2O3," J.E. Slimak et al., Physical Review Research 2, 043169 (2020);

(iv). "Inelastic light scattering studies of novel magnetodielectric mechanisms in transition metal CoCr2O3 and rare earth Co2O3", Astha Sethi, UIUC PhD thesis, 2020;

(v). "Temperature and magnetic field dependent Raman study of electron-phonon interactions in thin films of Bi2Se3 and Bi2Te3 nanoflakes," S. Buchenau et al., Physical Review B 101, 245431 (2020);

(vi). "Soft-phonon anomalies and crystal electric field/phonon coupling in cubic lanthanide sesquioxides Eu2O3 and Yb2O3", J.E. Slimak et al., Physical Review B 108, 045128 (2023);

(vii). "Direct confirmation of long-range magnetic order and evidence for multipoles in Ce2O3", A. Cote et al., arXiv:2303.11878 (2023), submitted to Physical Review B;

(viii). “Quantum magnetism in cerium-based binary compounds,” Alexandra Cote, UIUC PhD thesis, 2023;

(ix). “CEF-phonon interactions in rare-earth sesquioxides: pressure-, temperature-, and magnetic-field-dependent Raman scattering studies”, John Eddie Slimak, UIUC PhD thesis.

(3). Growing single crystal samples of magnetically responsive materials that were available to others in the scientific community.

(4). Expanding access and representation in STEM fields through various programs: (i) Throughout the funding cycle of this grant, the PI also served as the co-PI of the Illinois Sloan Center for Exemplary Mentoring, which has recruited -- and is successfully mentoring to degree completion -- over 150 PhD students from historically underrepresented groups in 14 STEM programs on campus.  The PI also served as the academic mentor specifically for 23 Sloan Scholar PhD students in the Dept. of Physics. (ii) The PI served as the APS Partnership Program coordinator of the Illinois Physics MS-to-PhD Bridge program, affiliated with the American Physical Society Bridge Program, which aims to expand representation in Physics PhD programs. (iii) The PI was also involved with the American Physical Society-sponsored "Inclusive Graduate Education Network" (IGEN).

(5). Science outreach to the public: The PI co-hosted the "Science at the Market" outreach effort at the Farmers Market at Lincoln Square mall in Urbana, Illinois, from May 2018 - October 2020 and May 2022 - October 2023. As part of this scientific outreach effort, experts from different STEM fields at the University of Illinois and Parkland College host a booth at the Urbana Farmer's Market to give scientific demonstrations and answer questions from the general public about the researchers' disciplines. See https://physics.illinois.edu/outreach/science-at-the-market.

(6). Improving the scientific communication skills of STEM graduate and undergraduate students: (i) The PI developed and taught a scientific writing course for graduate students, "Communicating Science Research" (Phys 598 PEN/Phys 595) each spring semester throughout the funding cycle of this grant, 2018-2023. This course has provided scientific writing and presentation skills training—including practice writing journal publications, referee reports, abstracts, and proposals—to more than 140 PhD and MS degree students from 8 STEM departments; and (ii) during the funding period for this grant, the PI was also involved in a project supported by the UIUC College of Engineering (and now funded by NSF on a separate grant) on "Improving the writing skills of undergraduate engineering students,” which aims to improve the scientific writing curriculum for science and engineering undergraduates. 

(7). Graduate student career guidance: The PI ran a Physics Careers Seminar series throughout the funding cycle of this grant -- inviting 68 alumni speakers from industry, national labs, and academia between 2018 and 2023 -- to provide PhD students information about their diverse career opportunities and to disseminate practical career advice for both academic and non-academic career paths. See https://physics.illinois.edu/academics/graduates/physics-careers-archive.
